historyLandmarks.name: Wawel Castle
historyLandmarks.description: A castle residency located in central Kraków, Poland, and one of the largest in the country.

historyLandmarks.name: Warsaw Uprising
historyLandmarks.description: A major World War II operation by the Polish resistance Home Army to liberate Warsaw from Nazi Germany.

historyLandmarks.name: Auschwitz-Birkenau
historyLandmarks.description: A network of German Nazi concentration camps and extermination camps built during World War II.

historyLandmarks.name: Salt Mine
historyLandmarks.description: A historic salt mine, one of the oldest in the world, offering underground tours.

historyLandmarks.name: Gdańsk Old Town
historyLandmarks.description: A picturesque historic district with colorful buildings and a maritime atmosphere.

historyLandmarks.name: Jasna Góra Monastery
historyLandmarks.description: A famous Polish shrine to the Virgin Mary and an important place of pilgrimage.

historyLandmarks.name: Białowieża Forest
historyLandmarks.description: An ancient forest, one of the last and largest remaining parts of the primeval forest that once covered much of Europe.

historyLandmarks.name: Malbork Castle
historyLandmarks.description: A 13th-century castle built by the Teutonic Knights, the largest castle in the world by land area.

historyLandmarks.name: Warsaw Old Town
historyLandmarks.description: The oldest part of the capital city of Poland, meticulously rebuilt after World War II.

historyLandmarks.name: Tatra Mountains
historyLandmarks.description: The highest mountain range in the Carpathians, offering stunning natural scenery and hiking trails.
